messageBody:
Russell Gold <russgold@...> wrote on 23.09.2004 16:03:25:
> A simple analogy: have you ever seen a stone arch being built? If not,
> can you picture how it must be done? Once all the stones are in place,
> they stay there because none of them can fall through the others. But
> how do you get them there in the first place? Image trying to hold all
> the stones in place simultaneously while you try to get the keystone
> set. You would drop a lot of them and get really frustrated. But a
> mason first builds a simple wooden form shaped like the interior of
> the arch and piles the stones on it. Then he takes it away when they
> are in place. Even though he has done this "extra work" of building
> the form, it is faster and more reliable to do it that way. It is the
> same thing with developer unit tests.

Hy,

although I think you miss the original posters point (as he knows about
test-first and seems to use it when possible but asks what to do when he's
forced to test-last) I like that analogy a lot. It really captures the
essence of test-driven development and can probably be successfully used
to describe tests-first to non-developers (PHB & Co).

regards
Joachim Sauer
